key_behaviors: Uses AI for simple, structured factual queries
Uses AI to add events to calendar and schedule
Uses AI only a couple of times per week
Prefers native UI because it is faster
Avoids AI when dealing with sensitive data
Avoids AI because of hallucination risk
pain_points: AI often hallucinates or provides inaccurate answers
Responses can be generic and lack useful detail
AI does not have deep contextual understanding of source material
AI is slower than using the built‑in UI of apps
AI cannot handle complex work‑related questions that require expertise
No reliable way to feed sensitive personal data into AI
trust_factors: Deep domain expertise and contextual awareness
desires: An AI that is perfectly accurate all the time
Deep, expert‑level understanding that can provide personalized insights
Speed comparable to native app interfaces
Ability to handle complex, context‑rich tasks without generic filler

verbatim_quotes.quote: I use AI for things that are really simple and structured, like asking questions where online, where I want specific answers.
I use the AI to calendar and schedule I think that's probably it for my personal life.
ChatGPT, and then internally, I and boost.
I use it maybe a couple times a week.
Types of questions are, like, just basic facts about the world, like dates, names, greeting information, just like what you might Google search.
I find the AI most helpful for things where doesn't require a lot of thinking, ... accuracy is more likely.
I mean, most of the things that I do in my life, I do not use AI because AI is likely to hallucinate, and I just don't have access to my sensitive data.
AI isn't as fast as just using the UI that I use in all of my apps and services.
There are oftentimes where AI isn't accurate.
The direct answers are often or I have seen AI be incorrect or provide generic answers that may on the surface appear correct, but are not at a level of detail that's useful.
Ask it a general question about a study that you've completed. It will just generally say things like, need more personalization or mobile parity or whatever.

because AI is not actually thinking. It just is taking the inputs and providing what is, like, a reasonable or a response that seems reasonable but it's not it doesn't actually have deep context or understanding about the source material.
It would just need, like, years of understanding of like, it's just, like, how expertise is developed.
The technology would have to be reliably accurate a hundred percent of the time, which is unlikely.
Accuracy. Because if it's not going to do it accurately, then what's the point of doing it at all?
It was fine. I thought the keyboard clicking sounds were unnecessary.
AI is obviously not doing that. So it doesn't need to do that.
there were a lot of double barreled so I wasn't it was hard to follow some of your questions.

unique_insights: The participant treats AI as a low‑stakes, fact‑retrieval tool comparable to a search engine and explicitly refuses to rely on it for any task that requires deep understanding, expertise, or handling of sensitive data. Their trust threshold is absolute—only 100% accuracy would make them comfortable—highlighting a stark contrast with many users who accept occasional errors. Additionally, they critique the interview interface itself (keyboard sounds, double‑barreled questions), indicating that even meta‑experience with AI systems can affect user perception.
